Introduction

Social media is an important way for organisations and people to share opinions, information and knowledge. Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) uses corporate social media channels to engage with staff, patients, public and other stakeholders.

Use of social media in people's own time in a personal capacity and without identifying themselves as employees of, or being associated with, the Trust and without discussing their work would not normally fall under the remit of this policy. Professional codes of conduct often do include personal social media accounts, and this policy assumes that staff will comply with policies set out by their professional or regulatory bodies.
Use of social media by members of the public cannot be governed by this policy, but our house rules in Appendix 1 set out how we expect people to behave in relation to our social media channels.
Scope
This policy applies to all MSE NHS Trust employees, including apprentices, contractors, volunteers, non-executive directors and governors, covering personal and organisational accounts.
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide guidance for using social media, ensuring that the Trust, staff and service users are not brought into disrepute as a result of the inappropriate use of social media
Provide a framework for the use of social media accounts operated on behalf of the Trust to ensure they are managed consistently and in line with information governance requirements.
Support staff using social media for professional development, for example through a personal account that identifies them as a Trust employee and used to discuss professional issues.
Definitions

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Chief Commercial Officer has overall responsibility for this policy.
Associate Director of Communications and Engagement has responsibility for protecting and promoting the reputation of the Trust and for dealing with media issues arising from social media.

The Head of Digital and Marketing Communications has responsibility for social media policy monitoring, development and implementation, and the strategic development of social media tools for corporate use.
The Complaints and PALS Manager has responsibility for responding to public comments via official NHS websites including NHS Choices and Patient Opinion.

All Trust employees and those working within the Trust have a duty to ensure that they adhere to the guidelines set out in this policy. If a member of staff is concerned about something relating to the Trust that they see on social media, it is their professional responsibility to inform their line manager, the communications team and/or the Trust's raising concerns lead.
Management of corporate social media accounts
Our corporate accounts and what they do

We have corporate accounts on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn and YouTube. These accounts are owned and managed solely by the communications and engagement team and monitored Monday to Friday 9am – 5pm.
We encourage staff to contact the communications team if they want to share news, events or messages relating to their work on our corporate accounts.
Social media management is undertaken by the digital communications team through a third-party management dashboard, Orlo.
Tone of voice and types of post Our corporate accounts
Support our corporate objectives
Promote good news stories about the Trust
Announce new service developments and examples of innovation and good practice
Support local, regional and national campaigns
Promote key messages about our services
Give information about changes to services
We adopt a friendly, first person tone of voice in line with our corporate values.
We use photographs and graphics, hashtags and links in line with our and the NHS brand, and adhere to accessibility guidelines for social media.
Requests for content to be posted through corporate channels can be made through our electronic request form (See Appendix 2).
Interactions
We
Respond to direct messages by signposting enquiries to the right department or external agency
Monitor and respond, where appropriate, to comments on our posts
Monitor and respond, where appropriate, to posts that tag our accounts
Escalate posts to managers within our organisation and to regional, national and/or external partners where they raise concerns about safety, care or inappropriate behaviour
Monitoring and responding to comments on corporate channels
Responding to comments
Our social media channels are checked throughout the day between 9 and 5, and comments and direct messages are usually responded to within two hours on a working day.
Our Facebook account sends an automatic reply to anyone sending a direct message that details working hours and provides a link to PALS information and NHS.uk.
Comments and queries received outside of working hours are responded to the next working day.
Comments requiring input from another department are passed on to the right person to provide an answer directly to the enquirer.

If comments and queries posted outside of working hours on Twitter or Facebook represent a risk to patient safety or a serious risk to the Trust's reputation the Communications manager on call will respond.

If comments or queries are received in a foreign language, we respond in English asking “How can we help?”. Online translation tools must not be used to attempt to formulate a response in a foreign language.
Medical advice

We do not provide medical advice on social media channels; individuals with medical questions are advised to contact their local GP, NHS111 or to call 999 in an emergency. Photographs and/or personal details are passed on to relevant departments where appropriate and then deleted.
Critical comments
The majority of social media comments about our Trust are positive but there are times when people post criticism or our Trust, services or staff.

People regularly use social media to comment on the quality of goods and services. This is especially important within the NHS and the wider public sector, as it gives a voice to people who would otherwise feel they couldn't raise legitimate concerns.
When we receive positive comments about our services we thank the poster and share with the appropriate department/s.

When we receive comments that are critical about our services we will respond in a positive way, inviting the individual to contact our Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS) to discuss the matter in detail, and maintain contact with the person who has contact us until they are satisfied that we've ‘handed over' their complaint properly.

When we receive comments that are critical about our Trust or staff we don't engage in detailed discussions. We will do our best to take the conversation offline by signposting the person to the PALS or complaints team and sometimes, but not always, will send a direct message to the person advising on the best contact to address their concern.

If comments harass, intimidate or threaten our staff in relation to actions or competencies relating to the care they have provided on behalf of our Trust, the communications team will work with them, the HR team and, if required, the legal team to take appropriate action.
If staff receive personal attacks on a personal social media profile, the communications team can offer advice but cannot take action on their behalf.
If we believe that comments are untrue, unfair or damaging to our reputation, we may make simple, factual statements and invite the individual to discuss the matter further offline.
The way that we engage with members of the public – and the way we expect them to engage with our social media channels – is outlined in our House Rules, see Appendix
Social media principles

Everyone choosing to use social media should be aware that their activity can be traced back to them. The conversations that you take part in and the things that you share about yourself can be enough to identify that you work for the Trust, even if you don't say that in your profile.

Individuals should take responsibility for protecting their own security online, including but not limited to restricting access to their accounts, blocking unwanted followers and reporting hacked accounts to the platform provider.

We encourage staff who want to have a presence on social media channels which in some way connects them to our Trust - for example, referring to the Trust in their profile, interacting with or commenting on Trust content in a way which indicates they are a member of staff, etc. - to do so in a way that upholds our values and maintains or amplifies the work we do to deliver our corporate objectives. This means that social media activity should at the very least not undermine the Trust's work to promote positive and supportive health messaging, showcasing best practice, innovations and achievements.

A disclaimer like ‘these views are personal and not necessarily those of my employer' is useful but no guarantee that posts or activity will not have a bearing on the Trust's or your reputation, either formally or informally.

Comments and content posted by staff on social media channels express the views of the people submitting them. Unless comments are posted by an authorised user of the Trust's corporate social media accounts, by an approved departmental account, or are retweeted/reposted by the official accounts, these comments don't necessarily reflect the view of the Trust.
When using social media, or while online in any capacity, you should not:
Reveal confidential information about our patients, staff or the business activities of the Trust – this includes photographing patients or colleagues without their consent
Engage in any activities which might bring the Trust into disrepute
Use the internet in any way to attack or abuse colleagues, patients or visitors to our Trust sites
Post defamatory, derogatory or offensive comments about colleagues, patients, visitors, your work or Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust itself
Post defamatory, derogatory, discriminatory or offensive comments that could be perceived as bullying or harassment - please read the Trust's Bullying and Harassment policy

Express grievances about your job, your colleagues or the Trust – instead follow the appropriate policy or procedure including the Grievance and Dignity at Work Policy or the Raising concerns (whistleblowing) procedure.
Respond to requests for interview or opinion by journalists or members of the press – instead follow the Communications and Media Relations policy and direct them to contact the communications team

All social media activity by any member of staff must adhere to the Trust's policies on confidentiality and information governance, internet usage, and declarations of interests, gifts, sponsorship and hospitality. Staff are individually responsible for content they post or publish online, and should use discretion and common sense in all social media activity.

This includes any individually-identifiable information about patients or people, including those featured in the background of photos/video footage or other content. Any activity by staff which brings the Trust into disrepute - including posting, re- posting, commenting on or otherwise endorsing inappropriate content - could result in the Trust's disciplinary procedures being invoked.
Individuals using social media in any professional capacity should follow the following principles.
Be transparent
In your profile, be honest and clear about who you work for, what your role is, what you're interested in and reflect some of your personality.

If you do enter into conversations in a professional capacity, identify yourself as working for our organisation and make clear that you are speaking in your own capacity and not on behalf of our Trust.
If you enter into conversations using a departmental account, you are speaking on behalf of the Trust.
Be friendly and approachable

Try to make your messages friendly; be professional but human, use the first person (‘I') and get involved in conversations. It's fine to express your personal opinions, as long as it's obvious that's what they are, but only say things that you would in a crowded room.
Be accurate and honest and mindful of spelling and grammar

It's fine to say ‘I do not know' if something is not your area of expertise. You can always tag someone in who may know and can help, or offer to put the person in touch with the right person/department using other channels like phone or email. That way you're opening up the conversation to others. It's far better to be clear and check with an expert than to share wrong information.

While everyone can make an occasional mistake, correct spelling and grammar (including correct use of apostrophes) will positively influence how your account is perceived and affect your reputation. Minimise your use of abbreviations where possible and don't assume everyone will understand jargon.
Participate, do not dictate

Social media is about having conversations to build relationships. The most important thing is that you are part of those conversations. So, you can really help by trying to add something useful, valuable or helpful to every interaction.
Do not name our Trust in your personal account handle
Using MSE, Mid and South Essex or any other variation of our Trust name in your handle, for example, @JohnSmithMSE will give the wrong impression that you are acting on behalf of the organisation.
Do name our Trust in departmental account handles
If you've received authorisation to set up and run a departmental account, you should include our Trust's name in your handle. See Appendix 2
Do not say anything you would not say in a crowded room

Do not swear, use aggressive, abusive, discriminatory or antagonistic language or get political. Use common sense and do not post anything that could be seen as damaging to your or our Trust's reputation.
Do not discuss patients or patient care

If you're approached online by a patient or relative, be clear that social media is not the right way to discuss care or raised concerns, and direct them to contact the Trust through the right channels.

Never comment on anything related to legal matters or complaints. If you're not sure if something's about a legal issue, it's best not to comment at all. This applies to statements coming from our corporate accounts, and to comments on our corporate channel posts – the communications team will handle public comments in line with our processes.
Do not get involved during a crisis

In the event of a major incident, staff must not film or show on social media anything relating to an ongoing incident or its response. This is to ensure integrity of policy and other emergency response. For further information, please refer to the Trust's Emergency preparedness, resilience and response policy and associated plans.

During major incidents it's better to have just one, official source of news and information, and this could be an external agency such as the police force, fire service or regional NHS organisation. Be mindful of what you say externally on any social networking sites as it can easily be picked up by the media. Look to internal channels such as the intranet or all staff emails for guidance during major incidents.
When sharing content, make sure you credit the original source

It's fine to link to external content, especially if it's of value to the conversation but make sure you credit the correct source. If you're not sure of the original source, at least tag the person you received it from.
Admit your mistakes

Mistakes happen and that's OK. The best thing to do when these occur is to admit it, apologise and correct it. Don't delete the content in the hope it will go away or pretend you're in the right, and if you're not sure, contact the communications department for help.
Pause

We all sometimes get into uncomfortable conversations. Before responding, it's always a good idea to take a moment to consider your response. Show it to a colleague or contact the communications department.
Talk amongst your team
Be aware of our key corporate messages and try not to contradict these.
Quality over quantity

You don't need to post every day to add a valuable voice to our messaging - it's a conversation, not an obligation. However, if you want to engage with your peers or other audience, you should aim for regular high quality posts.
Don't make big announcements

If you have a big announcement, such as innovation or service development, award nomination, or any good new story, let the communications team know first. We can work with you to amplify your message through all our communications channels to ensure you get maximum coverage. We understand the temptation to post big news quickly, but sharing too soon can undermine other communications plans that you might not be aware of, and may sometimes conflict with national guidance such as the pre-election purdah period when restrictions are in place around the announcements that public sector bodies can make.
Departmental accounts

A number of departmental social media accounts, created before our Trust merged, are run by staff across the Trust. The communications team will undertake an audit of these accounts during 2021/22 to ensure they
Are still in use by a member of staff working in our organisation
Are operating within the boundaries of this policy
Have shared their username and password with the communications team to protect our organisation in case of hacking or malicious use

All new requests for departmental social media accounts must come through the digital and marketing communications team to assess the need for the account and establish clear and measurable objectives for success.

In many cases departmental accounts are not appropriate, and better reach and coverage can be gained by channelling content through the Trust's corporate accounts and other communications channels, or by setting up an individual professional account.
Training
It's essential that staff members running a departmental account have clear objectives and aims to help determine how they will run their account.

Staff wishing to set up a social media account for their department are required to complete the initial request at Appendix 2 and submit to the communications team, who will arrange to have a conversation about the request.
Unauthorised accounts

If an account is set up without prior approval, the communications team will make contact via messaging or comment, requesting that the account owner gets in contact so we can provide support and gain the username and password for the account in case of hacking or malicious use. The communications team will then work with the account owner to establish objectives for success.

If the communications team is unable to make contact with account owners after repeated requests, or if posts originating from an authorised or unauthorised account breach this policy, the account will be reported through the relevant platform's processes for impersonating a verified account or for posting false content, with a view to having the account permanently removed.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Appendix 1: Social media house rules on the mse.nhs.uk website

The following copy is available on our Trust website www.mse.nhs.uk and outlines the way that we expect members of the public to interact with our social media channels, and the measure we will take to ensure a safe online environment for our patients, staff and public.

The Communications team at Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) is responsible for several different social media accounts on a number of platforms. We run accounts on the following channels: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube, LinkedIn.

We have put these guidelines in place to help create and maintain an environment where our community can engage, make comments, ask questions and share their experiences of our services on all social media channels run by us.
We are always interested in hearing from you and ask if you use our channels please show courtesy, kindness and respect for all other members.
If you have a question about patient care we always advise that you talk to a member of the team who is treating you or your relative so that they can answer your questions directly.
If you have a question about an appointment, you can visit our appointments page [link]

If you need confidential advice, support or information on health-related matters you can contact our PALS team PALS (Patient Advice and Liaison Service) at MSE | Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
How we use social media
If you follow us on social media, we do not automatically follow back. Being followed, using hashtags or mentioning other accounts does not imply endorsement of any kind.
We will retweet or share where we think it is useful or interesting but, again, this is not an endorsement.

We update and monitor our social media accounts during normal office hours, Monday to Friday. Social media platforms may occasionally be unavailable and we accept no responsibility for our lack of service due to any downtime.
Views and feedback
We welcome feedback, ideas and engagement and will try to join the conversation where possible, and where it is right to do so.

We monitor all compliments, complaints and emerging themes and pass reports about feedback to colleagues in relevant hospital departments, as well as sharing information about social media posts with our Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS), complaints team and patient experience team.
We may use your contact information or usernames to respond to messages or comments you send to us. If you post publicly on social media, we may share or retweet your post with our followers.
You can unsubscribe or unfollow us at any time.
Our House Rules
By engaging with our social media channels you agree to follow these guidelines:
all users must comply with the social media platform's terms of use, as well as these terms of use
you are wholly responsible for all the content you post, including any content that you choose to share
we will remove, in whole or in part, or ignore posts that we feel are inappropriate
we will report and remove any social media profiles that are set up using our Trust's name and/or imagery without permission
We will remove, block, ban and/or report users to the associated social media platform who direct messages at us which we believe:
We will also remove, block, report or ban any user who:

Hopefully we will not have to do this, but if we do, we hope you understand the reasons. Comments made on our social media accounts will not affect or influence the treatment, care or other services we provide to individuals, unless the behaviours also trigger the requirements of our Managing Violence and Aggression policy.
Responding
We'll do our best to respond to your enquiries during the working day within two hours.
We'll try to help you, or direct you to people and/or departments who can, wherever possible.
Our working hours are 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday. We'll deal with enquiries and messages sent outside of this time as soon as possible when working hours resume.
We do not respond to messages of a commercial nature.
It is important to note that all comments and postings by followers on this site ("User Content") do not necessarily reflect the opinions of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

When comments and queries posted outside of working hours on Twitter and Facebook represent a risk to patient safety or a serious risk to the Trust's reputation, the Communications manager on-call will respond.
We reserve the right to modify or change these house rules at any time. Accessibility
We aim to make our social media as accessible as possible for our communities, and there are a number of ways we do this:
Adding image descriptions to photos on social platforms
Using CamelCase in hashtags to ensure that screen readers interpret hashtags correctly
Adding subtitles to videos
Privacy
We are committed to protecting and respecting your privacy. We may use analytics or third parties to analyse our social media channels for trends, insights and engagement.
What to do if you see something that doesn't look right

If you spot any content or comments posted on our social media channels which you believe are not in accordance with these house rules, please report it to mse.communications@nhs.net and/or send a message through the relevant social media channel.
